articles.headline: ‘Our Bubble Has Been Burst’: Older Storm Victims Face an Uncertain Future
articles.snippet: Retirees displaced by Hurricane Ian confront a wrenching situation: At their age, remaking the lives they loved so much in Florida may not be possible.
articles.abstract: Retirees displaced by Hurricane Ian confront a wrenching situation: At their age, remaking the lives they loved so much in Florida may not be possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Mastriano’s Attacks on Jewish School Set Off Outcry Over Antisemitic Signaling
articles.snippet: The G.O.P. candidate for governor, who promotes Christian power and disdains separation of church and state, is alarming Jewish voters in his contest with the Democratic candidate, Josh Shapiro, who is Jewish.
articles.abstract: The G.O.P. candidate for governor, who promotes Christian power and disdains separation of church and state, is alarming Jewish voters in his contest with the Democratic candidate, Josh Shapiro, who is Jewish.
articles.lead_paragraph: MERION STATION, Pa. — Four years after the massacre at a Pittsburgh synagogue, believed to be the deadliest antisemitic attack in American history, Doug Mastriano, the Republican nominee for governor of Pennsylvania, has rattled a diverse swath of the state’s Jewish community, alarming liberal Jews with his remarks and far-right associations, and giving pause to more conservative ones.

articles.headline: With Attacks on Ukraine, Putin Gives Hard-Liners What They Wanted
articles.snippet: A sharp shift toward deadly strikes signaled that domestic pressure over Russia’s flailing war effort had escalated to the point where Vladimir Putin felt a decisive show of force was necessary.
articles.abstract: A sharp shift toward deadly strikes signaled that domestic pressure over Russia’s flailing war effort had escalated to the point where Vladimir Putin felt a decisive show of force was necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — For months, Russia’s state news media has insisted that the country was hitting only military targets in Ukraine, leaving out the suffering that the invasion has brought to millions of civilians.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: Putin Unleashes Barrage of Missiles on Ukrainian Civilian Areas
articles.snippet: The Russian president tied the attack to a bombing of the bridge to Crimea, and vowed that more strikes would follow if Russian targets were hit again.
articles.abstract: The Russian president tied the attack to a bombing of the bridge to Crimea, and vowed that more strikes would follow if Russian targets were hit again.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — President Vladimir V. Putin unleashed a far-reaching series of missile strikes against cities across Ukraine on Monday, hitting the heart of Kyiv and other areas far from the front line, in the broadest assault against civilians since the early days of Russia’s invasion.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia and Eric Nagourney

articles.headline: Can This Man Solve Europe’s Energy Conundrum?
articles.snippet: Marco Alverà has big plans to produce a “green gas” from hydrogen that uses existing infrastructure.
articles.abstract: Marco Alverà has big plans to produce a “green gas” from hydrogen that uses existing infrastructure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe’s energy crisis is rooted in its love affair with natural gas, and now its citizens are paying the price for dependence on gas piped in from Russia. At the same time, Europe’s lawmakers and businesses are searching for an alternative that could keep its homes warm and power factories yet help the continent reach its climate goals.

articles.headline: Meet the App That Helps Gig Workers Know How Much They Really Make
articles.snippet: A former Uber employee created an app to help drivers. The platforms that hire them are fighting back.
articles.abstract: A former Uber employee created an app to help drivers. The platforms that hire them are fighting back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber says its drivers average $30 an hour. The delivery service DoorDash says its drivers make at least $25. In reality, many of their drivers aren’t sure how much they make when taking all their costs into account.

articles.headline: Biden Proposal Could Lead to Employee Status for Gig Workers
articles.snippet: A proposed rule, long awaited by labor activists, would make it harder for companies to classify workers as independent contractors.
articles.abstract: A proposed rule, long awaited by labor activists, would make it harder for companies to classify workers as independent contractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department on Tuesday unveiled a proposal that would make it more likely for millions of janitors, home-care and construction workers and gig drivers to be classified as employees rather than independent contractors.

articles.headline: A Warning for the World Economy: ‘The Worst Is Yet to Come’
articles.snippet: The International Monetary Fund lowered its growth outlook for 2023 and suggested that interest rate increases could spur a harsh global recession.
articles.abstract: The International Monetary Fund lowered its growth outlook for 2023 and suggested that interest rate increases could spur a harsh global recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday that the world economy was headed for “stormy waters” as it downgraded its global growth projections for next year and warned of a harsh worldwide recession if policymakers mishandled the fight against inflation.

articles.headline: Biden Vows ‘Consequences’ for Saudi Arabia After Oil Production Cut
articles.snippet: Angered by the kingdom’s decision to team up with Russia, President Biden signaled openness to retaliatory measures, including a halt to arms sales and allowing price-fixing lawsuits.
articles.abstract: Angered by the kingdom’s decision to team up with Russia, President Biden signaled openness to retaliatory measures, including a halt to arms sales and allowing price-fixing lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden vowed on Tuesday to impose “consequences” on Saudi Arabia for teaming up with Russia to cut oil production, signaling a rupture in the relationship between two longtime allies and a reversal of his own effort to cultivate the energy-rich kingdom.
